conclusion: The light source is initially positioned above the objects, casting shadows directly below them.
When the light source moves backward, it will be further away from the objects.
As the light source moves backward, the shadows will move forward (towards the objects).
The size of the shadows will decrease due to the inverse square law of light.
Object A appears to be a cylindrical object with a flat top.
The shadow (A) will move forward and become smaller.
Object B appears to be an egg-shaped object.
The shadow (B) will move forward and become smaller.
Object C appears to be a small, irregularly shaped object.
The shadow (C) will move forward and become smaller.
Object D appears to be a rectangular object with a grid pattern.
The shadow (D) will move forward and become smaller.
Final Answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D move forward and become smaller.
